visual_confirmation_session.method_note: Batch 1 visual confirmation. For each manuscript: navigated to YEK detail page, extracted internal IIIF ID via network interception, opened viewer (Goruntu button), navigated thumbnails in nested iframes (OpenSeadragon in easyXDM), took viewport screenshots. IIIF direct download failed (HTTP/2 ping error, CORS) so all screenshots are viewer captures (~1536x864 px). Screenshots saved to corpus/visual_confirmation_batch1/.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows cover/doublure, p005 shows flyleaf, p007 and p010 show text pages with gold sprinkling clearly visible on margins.

evidence.observation: Text opening in naskh script. Gold particles clearly visible across the paper surface, particularly in the margin areas. Warm golden tone distinct from plain paper. Dense, uniform sprinkling pattern consistent with zerefsan technique.
Continuation of text. Same gold sprinkling pattern confirmed on margins. Consistent with p007 -- uniform application across the manuscript pages.

limitations: Viewer resolution (~1536x864) sufficient for confirmation but individual particle morphology not resolvable
4 of 23 pages examined; sprinkling appears uniform across sampled pages
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Confirmed. Pass to motif-classifier. Same physical volume as yek_id 121026.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: Same mecmua (physical volume) as yek_id 121027. p007 shows text pages with identical gold sprinkling.

evidence.observation: Same physical volume as 121027. Gold sprinkling clearly visible, same density and pattern as the companion risale. Confirms catalogue claim for this text unit within the mecmua.

limitations: Only 1 page examined, but same physical volume as 121027 which was confirmed across 4 pages
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Confirmed. Pass to motif-classifier. Note: same physical volume as 121027; catalog record should cross-reference.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows opening pages, p005 shows text pages with small decorative elements between sections. No gold sprinkling visible anywhere.

evidence.observation: Opening pages visible. Paper is plain cream/buff colored with no gold particles, no metallic shimmer, no warm golden toning. Paper surface is uniform and undecorated.

Text pages with small decorative illuminated elements (palmettes, rosettes) scattered between text sections. These are 'serpme tezhip' = scattered illumination motifs applied to the page, NOT gold-sprinkled paper (zerefsan/serpme yaldiz). The paper itself is plain. The catalogue term 'serpme tezhiplidir' describes illumination pattern, not paper decoration.

limitations: Only 2 of 23 pages examined, but the two pages are representative of the manuscript's decoration
visual_confirmation.recommendation: NOT CONFIRMED for gold_sprinkled category. Reclassify as false positive: 'serpme tezhiplidir' means scattered illumination, not gold-sprinkled paper. The QC flag noted this ambiguity. Move to removed_false_positives in registry.
visual_confirmation.discrepancies: Catalogue term 'serpme tezhiplidir' was initially interpreted as gold-sprinkled paper but actually describes scattered illumination motifs between text sections. This is a semantic false positive: 'serpme' (scattered) modifies 'tezhip' (illumination), not paper decoration.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 and p007 both show text pages with distinctive green-tinted margins consistent with oxidized gold.

evidence.observation: Text pages visible. Margins show a distinctive greenish-grey discoloration, different from the cream-white text area. This tonal shift is consistent with oxidized gold sprinkling (gold leaf particles oxidize to a dark green/brown tone over centuries).
Same greenish-grey margin discoloration confirmed on additional pages. Pattern is consistent across examined pages and matches the catalogue description of 'oksitlenmis yaldiz' (oxidized gold).

limitations: Oxidized gold loses its metallic shine, making it hard to distinguish from other paper discolorations at viewer resolution
Individual gold particles not resolvable; verdict based on tonal pattern matching the catalogue description
Greenish margin toning could theoretically be foxing or water damage, though the catalogue specifically identifies it as oxidized gold
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable. Pass to motif-classifier with note about oxidation state. Physical examination recommended to confirm gold particles under magnification.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 and p005 show text pages with clear gold sprinkling on blue-grey tinted paper with gold cetvels (ruling lines).

evidence.observation: Text pages on distinctively blue-grey tinted paper. Dense gold particles clearly visible across the paper surface, creating a warm shimmer against the cool-toned paper. Gold ruling lines (cetvels) frame the text block. The combination of zerefsan on colored paper is striking and unambiguous.
Consistent with p003. Gold sprinkling continues uniformly. Blue-grey paper base confirmed. Gold cetvels visible. High-quality decorated paper throughout.

limitations: Only 2 pages examined out of available set
Viewer resolution sufficient for this manuscript due to high contrast between gold particles and blue-grey paper
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Confirmed with high confidence. Pass to motif-classifier. Notable specimen: zerefsan on colored (blue-grey) paper with cetvels. May also qualify as 'mixed' (gold_sprinkled + colored + framing_system).

catalogue_claim.location_claimed: throughout -- gold-sprinkled, marbled, colored, with gold cetvels
catalogue_claim.exact_text: Farkli renklerde, ebrulu, zerefsanli yaldiz cetvelli

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 and p005 show spectacular mixed decorated paper: gold sprinkling, marbled borders, colored paper, gold cetvels all clearly visible.

evidence.observation: Spectacular mixed decorated paper clearly visible. Gold sprinkling (zerefsan) on the main text area paper. Marbled (ebrulu) borders visible along the margins with colored patterns. Gold ruling lines (yaldiz cetvel) frame the text block. Multiple colors present in the paper and decorative elements. All elements described in the catalogue are visually confirmed.

Consistent with p003. All decoration elements continue: zerefsan on text area, marbled borders, gold cetvels, colored paper sections. This is one of the most elaborately decorated papers in the corpus.

limitations: Only 2 pages examined, but decoration is very prominent and unambiguous
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Confirmed with highest confidence in this batch. Pass to motif-classifier as priority specimen. Categories: gold_sprinkled + marbled + colored + framing_system. Exceptional example of mixed Ottoman decorated paper.

catalogue_claim.exact_text: Ilk formalarin derkenlari zerefsan teknigiyle suslenmistir

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows flyleaf with watermark. p005 shows the opening with serlevha (illuminated headpiece). Margins have a golden-tinged tone on the early folios.

evidence.observation: Opening page with illuminated serlevha. The margin areas of the early folios show a warm golden tint that is subtly different from plain paper. This is consistent with zerefsan applied to the margins (derkenlar) of the first gatherings. However, the tonal difference is subtle at viewer resolution and could be influenced by aging/foxing.

limitations: Zerefsan limited to margins of first gatherings only -- subtle effect at viewer resolution
Difficult to distinguish fine margin gold sprinkling from paper aging/yellowing at ~1536px width
Only early pages examined; later pages (without zerefsan per catalogue) not compared
A side-by-side comparison of early vs. late gatherings would strengthen this verdict
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable. Pass to motif-classifier with caveat about resolution limitations. Physical examination or higher-resolution imaging recommended to confirm gold particles in margin areas.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows text pages. Paper appears yellowish as described (sarimtirak) with possible gold shimmer but resolution insufficient to resolve individual particles.

evidence.observation: Text pages on yellowish paper matching the catalogue description ('sarimtirak' = yellowish). The paper surface has a slight shimmer/warmth that could be consistent with burnished gold sprinkling ('saykalli zerefsan'). However, burnished gold sprinkling produces a very fine, uniform appearance that is difficult to distinguish from naturally yellow-toned paper at this resolution.

limitations: Only 1 page examined
Burnished (saykalli) zerefsan produces very fine particles that are harder to detect than brush-applied sprinkling
Yellowish paper base makes gold sprinkling detection more difficult (low contrast)
Viewer resolution (~1536px) insufficient to resolve fine burnished gold particles
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable at low-moderate confidence. The catalogue specifically describes 'saykalli zerefsan' which is the hardest zerefsan subtype to confirm visually at low resolution. Physical examination needed.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p003 shows narrow conk (commonplace book) format pages. Some scattered particles visible on the paper surface.

evidence.observation: Narrow-format conk pages visible. Paper surface shows some scattered particles/specks that could be gold sprinkling. The paper has a slightly warm tone. However, at viewer resolution it is difficult to distinguish gold particles from paper impurities or foxing spots.

limitations: Only 1 page examined
Conk format is narrow -- less visible paper surface area in the viewer
Cannot distinguish gold particles from paper impurities at this resolution
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable at low-moderate confidence. Physical examination recommended. Catalogue is explicit ('zerefsan kagit') so the claim is well-supported textually.

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p001 shows inner covers/endpapers with elaborate floral decorated paper (roses, botanical motifs in color). The catalogue says this paper is zerefsan-covered.

evidence.observation: Inner covers and endpapers show beautiful floral decorated paper with roses, leaves, and botanical motifs in color on a light background. The catalogue describes this as 'zerefsan kagitla kaplanmistir' (covered with gold-sprinkled paper). Gold sprinkling may be present as a background technique on this decorative paper, but at viewer resolution it is difficult to distinguish gold particles from the overall warm tone of the floral paper. The presence of elaborate decorated endpaper paper is confirmed; whether it includes zerefsan specifically requires closer examination.

limitations: Only endpaper page examined (as directed by catalogue -- zerefsan is on endpapers, not text pages)
Floral paper decoration confirmed but specific gold sprinkling technique hard to distinguish from warm-toned decorative paper background
Viewer resolution insufficient to resolve fine gold particles on decorated paper
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Probable. The decorated endpaper paper is clearly visible and matches the catalogue description of endpaper covering. Whether zerefsan is the specific technique used on this paper requires physical examination or higher-resolution imaging.

catalogue_claim.location_claimed: paper throughout -- zerefsan paper with crown-bunch watermark

screenshots_examined.coverage_notes: p001 shows front cover (bordo leather). p003 shows opening pages with ownership stamps. p005 shows text pages in talik script. Paper appears cream/buff, zerefsan not clearly distinguishable at viewer resolution.

evidence.observation: Opening pages with ownership stamps and seals. Paper appears cream/buff colored. A watermark pattern is faintly visible (consistent with 'tacli salkim filigranli' = crown-bunch watermark). No clear gold sprinkling distinguishable at this resolution, but the paper tone is consistent with aged zerefsan paper.

Text pages in talik script. Paper surface appears uniform cream/buff. No distinct gold sprinkling visible at viewer resolution. The watermark is consistent with the catalogue description but the zerefsan cannot be confirmed or denied.

limitations: Viewer resolution (~1536px) insufficient to resolve fine gold particles on cream-colored paper
Low contrast between possible gold sprinkling and cream paper makes detection very difficult
Zerefsan on light paper is the hardest variant to detect remotely
3 pages examined, none showing clear evidence for or against
visual_confirmation.recommendation: Inconclusive. Cannot confirm or deny. The catalogue is explicit about 'zerefsan' paper, and the watermark description matches. Resolution is the limiting factor. Physical examination or IIIF at native resolution (if CORS issues are resolved) recommended.

71373.reason: 'Serpme tezhiplidir' describes scattered illumination motifs, not gold-sprinkled paper
